image.altText: Chris Martin performs on stage.

props.synopsis: A group of deaf and hard-of-hearing Coldplay fans say they were let down at the band's Perth show, having paid $220 for what they believed was an Auslan accessible ticket that included a number of services which were late or never provided.

title.children: Deaf and hard-of-hearing Coldplay fans let down by Perth show offered compensation

image.altText: An Aboriginal man named Bing Crosby and the American singer, Bing Crosby

props.synopsis: Across northern Australia, some Aboriginal people have grown up bearing the names of Hollywood stars and fascist dictators. It's a link back to a dark chapter in history.

title.children: 'The category of domestic animals': Aboriginal people named Hitler, Stalin and Bing Crosby

image.altText: A composite image of a bright red and white sign that says 'coles' and a white sign that says 'woolworths' with a green icon.

props.synopsis: The Greens say an inquiry can find a way to "dismantle" the power of Australia's two major supermarkets and bring down soaring grocery prices.

title.children: Coles defends its actions, as Senate looks to investigate major supermarkets

image.altText: A young girl and a woman can be seen smiling and waving inside a large car

props.synopsis: After 50 days of speculation about the hostages' welfare, this was a huge opportunity for Hamas to present a more human side, but most in the West saw straight through it.

title.children: When Hamas's hostages smile and wave, this is what's actually going on

image.altText: a skyline with houses

props.synopsis: Our suburbs have been turned into goldfields, creating millions of paper millionaires, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: There's a housing gold rush in Australia. Will you strike it rich?

image.altText: A storm rolls over Deniliquin

props.synopsis: After two weeks of storms and heavy rainfall lashed Australia's eastern states, there's little doubt that it has been a very wet November for many, defying the odds of a dry weather for spring. So what happened to El Niño?

title.children: November was wet. So what happened to El Niño?

image.altText: A black and white photo of a woman in a dark hat

props.synopsis: She may have been the master of the genre, but the only Agatha Christie mystery that can never be solved is her own strange and scandalous disappearance.

title.children: Agatha Christie was at the peak of her career when her husband dropped a bombshell. Then she disappeared

image.altText: A large orange ship approaches a bridge span

props.synopsis: The RSV Nuyina "hit" Hobart's Tasman Bridge four times during computer simulations, and would have done so another 10 times if the virtual trial wasn't aborted. It's why the ship now has to make a 660-kilometre detour to refuel at a cost of almost $1 million.

title.children: Australian Antarctic icebreaker's $875,000 refuelling debacle revealed in a single image

image.altText: A storm rolls over Deniliquin

props.synopsis: After two weeks of storms and heavy rainfall lashed Australia's eastern states, there's little doubt that it has been a very wet November for many, defying the odds of a dry weather for spring. So what happened to El Niño?

title.children: November was wet. So what happened to El Niño?

image.altText: Lance Morris stands in sunglasses

props.synopsis: Lance Morris may have a chance to start his highly anticipated international career after being named in the 14-man squad for the first Test against Pakistan, while David Warner appears set to be handed a fairytale end to his stellar career.

title.children: Lance Morris in line for Test debut, David Warner's farewell tour receives boost after Australia Test squad named

image.altText: Close-up of young woman with curly brown hair and freckles, holding her hand to her forehead and frowning with eyes closed.

props.synopsis: To finish the year feeling good, try putting these techniques into practice and prepare for a restful break, write Sophie Scott and Gordon Parker.

title.children: It's beginning to look a lot like burnout: How to take care of yourself before the holidays start

image.altText: Villawood Immigration Detention Centre

props.synopsis: The ABC understands new legislation aimed at locking up some of the non-citizens released following last month's landmark High Court ruling will go to cabinet on Monday morning.

title.children: Federal government to use existing Coalition-era terror laws as a basis for new preventative detention regime

image.altText: A brunette woman sits at a table holding a fabric swatch.

props.synopsis: Clothing can affect "one's core sense of identity" which is why it's so important that people with disabilities are able to access clothing that's not just accessible, but cute too.

title.children: 'Everything made me feel decades older than I was': Filling the void of fashionable clothing for different bodies

image.altText: Catherine O'Hara played Macaulay Culkin's mother in the 1990 film Home Alone and its 1992 sequel.

props.synopsis: Culkin is joined at the ceremony by his goddaughter Paris Jackson, siblings Rory and Quinn Culkin and actor Seth Green among others.

title.children: 'I'm so proud of you': Home Alone stars Macaulay Culkin and Catherine O'Hara reunite at Walk of Fame ceremony

image.altText: Cleveland Dodd's casket being carried to his grave.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of mourners gather for the funeral service for the teenager who died inside WA's juvenile detention system.

title.children: Coffin holding Cleveland Dodd's body lowered into the ground on Yamaji country after boy's death in custody

image.altText: large smoke plume on the horizon

props.synopsis: Environmental groups call for the federal environment minister to intervene over the burning of ancient peat swamps near Denmark in WA, just months after the area was listed as an endangered ecological community.

title.children: Conservationists, scientists demand answers over prescribed burning of important swamps

image.altText: Man wearing Werrimull Football Club shirt standing on oval, smiling

props.synopsis: Luke 'Huddo' Hudson, who lives with Down Syndrome, says there is always a way to achieve your dreams, even if you have to work out a unique way of getting there.

title.children: 'Huddo's fantastic': Luke is the heart and soul of this footy club, where he's living his dream

image.altText: People gathetr in the street in Butuan City after an earthquake.

props.synopsis: The earthquake triggers hundreds of aftershocks, with thousands of people across southern Philippines and parts of the south-west Japanese coast urged to flee.

title.children: Tsunami warnings lifted after Philippines magnitude-7.5 earthquake triggers hundreds of aftershocks

image.altText: light streaks from rocket interception above a lit up horizon in israel

props.synopsis: In the clearest sign yet that a return to negotiations for further truces is unlikely, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu orders his negotiators to leave ceasefire talks being held in Qatar.

title.children: Israel bombards crowded southern Gaza as Netanyahu withdraws negotiators from Qatar

image.altText: an aerial view of where trees were destroyed in sydney's castle cove

props.synopsis: This year two separate tree massacres in Sydney's wavefront suburbs has shocked residents and councils, who are asking for tougher laws.

title.children: More than 500 trees destroyed along Sydney's waterfront yet 'no-one heard anything'

image.altText: two runners on the top of a mountain ridge in regional victoria

props.synopsis: Western Victoria's jagged Grampians mountains have long been a favoured destination for hikers and climbers, but they're also emerging as a must for a new type of fitness fanatic.

title.children: A new breed of super-fit athlete is discovering the rugged trails of Victoria's Grampians and climbers aren't happy

image.altText: A woman wearing a light brown jumper stands next to a white picket fence.

props.synopsis: The use of third-party platforms by real estate agents to manage rental applications is already firmly embedded in Australia's rental market, but some are concerned regulation has fallen behind.

title.children: 'Show you're a great tenant': Third-party rental app add-ons contribute to renter woes

image.altText: CJ Brunton holds out his hands

props.synopsis: Adelaide 36s coach CJ Bruton and star Dejan Vasiljevic urge the NBL to look at scheduling after suffering a heavy loss to Tasmania on the road.

title.children: 'Give us a private jet': Adelaide slams NBL travel schedule after record loss

image.altText: Shot of cars lined up covered by snow

props.synopsis: Snowstorms and heavy winds lash parts of Europe and the US, grounding flights at Munich's airport and knocking out power across the US's Pacific Northwest.

title.children: Heavy snow and wind causes chaos across Europe and US

image.altText: Rows of solar panels. Blue sky dotted with white clouds.

props.synopsis: Australia joins more than 100 other countries across the globe in committing to a tripling of renewable energy capacity by the end of the decade in another coup for the organisers of this year's UN climate talks.

title.children: Australia commits to tripling of renewable energy capacity by end of decade

image.altText: A beetle with long antennae and a yellow and black back.

props.synopsis: When Jenny Purtell bought a Harvey Norman flat-pack bed for her son, she wasn't expecting a live beetle to crawl out of the the slats. It turns out the beetle species has never been detected in Australia before.

title.children: Flat-pack bed buy goes wrong after exotic beetle crawls out of hole

image.altText: Jemma Barsby celebrates

props.synopsis: The Adelaide Strikers are revelling in their heart-stopping three run win over the Brisbane Heat in the WBBL final, with Heat skipper Jess Jonassen regretting the difference two metres can make.

title.children: 'My heart stopped': Strikers joy as Heat bemoan 'game of margins'

image.altText: Old family photos show two identical twin sisters, Piper and Gabrielle, smiling.

props.synopsis: Growing up, my twin sister and I were inseparable. The longest we had ever spent apart was 24 hours. When Gabrielle moved to Sydney as an adult, the pain I felt was all-consuming.

title.children: 'It's like being homesick, but for a person': The loneliness of being separated from your twin

image.altText: A woman sits at a cafe bench near a car park.

props.synopsis: Tara Byrne, a busy professional, was sold a deal that would reduce her taxable income and provide cost-of-living relief, but the car she signed up for ended up costing more than double its showroom price.

title.children: Tara tried to save some of her pay going to tax but it ended up costing her thousands

image.altText: A composite image of Ange Postecoglou holding his head and Erling Haaland celebrating.

props.synopsis: Tottenham Hotspur has lost three straight Premier League matches and, with a trip to Manchester City on the cards plus a shocking injury list, Ange Postecoglou faces his toughest test.

title.children: Ange Postecoglou's nightmare November brought stunning start to a grinding halt — and it could get even worse

image.altText: four people stand in front of a pub

props.synopsis: Luc Longley and his wife, chef Anna Gare, are part of a group of local investors who have bought the historic Denmark Hotel in Western Australia with plans to renovate the popular watering hole.

title.children: Old pub's new-look reno close to NBA champion Luc Longley's heart
